I think it is the human condition; humans can build and destroy. This can be evidenced by plotting the history of mankind and the never-ending stream of wars and conflicts, interspersed with the need to build and create beautiful towns and cities. If you need a theory to support this apparent human dichotomy look no further than the work of Freud. He postulated the idea of the ‘ego’ the ‘id’ and the ‘super ego’. The id self is geared to out baser instincts such as pleasure, sex and aggression, whereas the super ego provides our inner voice of moral judgement, preventing our baser instincts from taking over. Some of his other work (Beyond the Pleasure Principle) also focused on the ideas of a ‘life instinct’ and a ‘death instinct’. The life instinct is vital for sustaining life and the continuation of the species, and behaviours that bolster such things as well-being, social cooperation and living in harmony. He set life instinct in opposition to ‘death instinct’, which he said was a self-destructive tendency in all of us. If we agree that Freud’s ideas are valid then this might explain the reasons why students prefer to destroy rather than create within the classroom. But I think it may be something more immediate than that. Maybe the students are aggressive because they feel their learning needs are not being met. They may be pushing the boundaries of the teacher’s authority. Students may also be testing the extent of their power over the environment and the things in it.
